Description: Ram's head-shaped scaraboid in Egyptian blue, probably mould-made; underside decorated with representation of bird, either a duck or a goose, walking to right, one wing above back; motif likely incised; pierced for suspension through diameter near the circular base, so head would hang down.
Curator's comments: This scaraboid was not seen by us. Scaraboids in the shape of a ram's head pertain to a common series assumed to have been produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). But no examples were found there, and no moulds for their manufacture, implying that though commonly found in Naukratis, they were being made elsewhere on the site?They are normally made in Egyptian blue, as here. The ram's head reproduces the rhyton shape popular in both Greek coroplastic and coins. This shape can also be related to the ram-headed god Amun-Ra of Baded, the main local Egyptian god revered at Naukratis. The goose, a sacred animal for Amun-Ra, or the duck, decorating the underside is a regular theme on scarabs and scaraboids from Naukratis. This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially found in Cartage, Cumae and Perachora (Gorton 1996, 114-117, type XXXII, subtype B7-11, see especially B9 for this specimen). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1925, Buttons and design scarabs: illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University College, London (British School of Archaeology in Egypt 38), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1925 / Buttons and design scarabs: illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University College, London (pl. XIV, no. 910)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 117, Type XXXII B9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.08) (phase 3)
